data.title: Exposure to heat and air pollution in EUrope – cardiopulmonary impacts and benefits of mitigation and adaptation
meta_keywords: Exposure to heat and air pollution in EUrope – cardiopulmonary impacts and benefits of mitigation and adaptation
data.meta_description: Deliverables, publications, datasets, software, exploitable results
data.text:
Deliverables

Literature review exposure response

Review of the evidence on individual and interactive/synergistic exposure-response relationships be-tween extreme temperatures, air pollution and cardiovascular and respiratory disease mortality and morbidity (by age, sex, and socio-economic status) for Europe. Output of T2.1.

Report on the design and development of adaptation scenarios for extreme temperature and air pollution

Definition of a set of adaptation pathways translated in measurable changes in specific vulnerability factors based on the key vulnerability factors identified in WP2 and consistent with broad socioeconomic and emissions trajectories applied in WP3 Output of T42

Methodology for models applicable for health impacts projections

Report on methods for integration of epidemiological evidence from the threelevel analysis performed in WP2 to derive 1 locationspecific exposureresponse functions informing on geographical variation health risks and 2 effect modification indices of health risks dependent on levels of a set of vulnerability factors The methods will form the basis for developing predictive models for Health impact projections Output of T43 and T44

Design Manual

The Design Manual will ensure that the project has a visual identity which includes design elements that can be used in combination with logo, logo (also negative), colour palette, typefaces, design of template for deliverables, presentations, reports, and fact sheets. Output of T6.2

Epidemiological methods for establishing exposure-response

Protocol on statistical analysis and examples (using samples of our data) to demonstrate protocol feasibility. As a part of the validation and wrt to the testing of novel features in our approach (such as the exposure-response functions for interactions) the report will also include sensitivity analyses to test the how specific parameters affect the performance. Output of T2.2.

Urban scale climate and air pollution projections

Report on downscaled temperature and air pollution at urban scale (1 km) (current and for future projection)

Wildland fire emission projections

Report on new highresolution future projections of wildland fire emissions under different SSP scenarios using the IS4FIRES model

Science policy briefs

To ensure active incorporation of the project results in decisionmaking the attendees at the stakeholder meetings will produce a sciencepolicy brief on the translation of EXHAUSTION results into political and societal decisions and regulationsOutcome of T64

Terms of reference (ToR) for AB and Agenda and Minutes from the first AB meeting.

Terms of reference (ToR) for Advisory Board, including confirmation of the composition of the AB and Agenda and Minutes from the first Advisory Board meeting. (Part of T1.3)

Exposure-response functions for interactive effects of temperature and air pollution

Exposureresponse functions ERF for interactive effects of temperature and air pollution The report presents the finding from the three levels of analyses MCC database with extensions smallarea data and cohort data regarding the potential interaction effects in the exposureresponse relationship for mortality and morbidity outcomes versus nonoptimal temperatures and air pollutants PM25 and O3 Results are presented separately for the different datasets and based on metaanalyses of the full material produced in the project Output of T23 and T24

Literature review on adaptive mechanisms

Systematic review of evidence on adaptive mechanisms, ranging from behavioural factors to public health policies, in relation with vulnerability to extreme temperature and air pollution. Output of T4.1.

Exposure-response functions for temperature and CPD mortality and morbidity

Exposureresponse functions for temperature and CPD mortality and morbidity The report presents the finding from the three levels of analyses MCC database with extensions smallarea data and cohort data regarding the exposureresponse relationship for mortality and morbidity outcomes versus nonoptimal temperatures Results are presented separately for the different datasets and based on metaanalyses of the full material produced in the projectOutput of T23 and T24

Dissemination, exploitation and communication strategy

Dissemination, exploitation and communication strategy. The DEC strategy will be updated annually. Output of T6.1

Assessment report climate change & air pollution links

Assessment of the state-of-the-art on the link and feedbacks between climate change and air pollution, including wildland fires. Output from T3.1.

White Paper

White Paper with key project findings, macroeconomic indicators for Europe-wide model pro-jections, as well as evaluation of economic benefits of adaptation and socio-economic impacts with geographical resolution.Output of T6.5

Project management plan

Project management plan (Part of T1.2)

Social and economic consequences of CPD under alternative socioeconomic scenarios

Report on projected social and economic consequences of changes in the CPD burdens under alternative projections for European countries. The projections provide a reference for evaluations of alternative long-term adaptation strategies. The projections will refer to the socioeconomic pathways underlying the climate projections, and will be based on output both from the EVA and the GRACE models. The projections will show impacts of climate change with attention to the health effects and related adaptation options on main economic indicators by sector and on unemployment rates over the coming decades. Output of T5.3 and T5.4.

Event at COP28

Dissemination and communication event at COP28Output of T6.4

Final stakeholder event in Brussels

Final stakeholder event in BrusselsOutput of T6.5

Data visualisation

Appealing data visualisations based on the estimates of the socio-economic impacts related to health risks under alternative climate change scenarios, including global 1.5°C and 2°C scenarios. These will be stand-alone, high-quality communication products that will also feed into the AR6 WG1, and that are intended both for scientific and non-scientific audiences. It has not yet been assessed if an interactive tool or platform will be an efficient solution. We await results from end-user insights to inform of the best solution. An interactive tool remains a potential option.Output of T6.4

Stakeholder meetings

The project will invite identified policy stakeholders on local and national levels in selected EU and EEA member states to stakeholder meetings. Members of the European Parliament and policy officers in the European Commission will be invited to these stakeholder meetings. Exhaustion will use the Advisory Board to aggregate more interest, multiply the network contact and to reach more relevant high-level representatives to the EU-level stakeholder meeting. Invitees to EU-level stakeholder meeting are selected based on relevant knowledge and opportunity to maximise impact through dissemination and exploitation of project outputs. Partners will be responsible for carrying out additional stakeholder meetings in their respective countries where they will recruit from new and existing networks.Output of T6.4

Two European events

Two European events.Event 1: Lead by CICERO in Northern EuropeEvent 2: Lead by UPORTO in Southern EuropeOutput of T6.4

Interactive tool

The interactive tool will be released in a newly-developed website and designed with a user-friendly interface. The tool will allow the user to select the type of results (impacts, risks), geographical area of interest and format (figures, maps, tables). It will include instructions of use, a tutorial with examples and a user-survey. As part of the implementation process of the tool, it will be initially released to a limited number of users to test its proper functioning. Output of T4.5.

Final version Citizen engagement tool

Final version Citizen engagement tool, including user survey: To establish the final version, user feedback will be taken into account. The specific modifications of the tool will emerge from the user requirements analysis. In addition, an internal evaluation within the EXHAUSTION team will be taken into account. Thus, D6.4 will describe the first version of the tool that will be offered to EFA, Quercus and the general public for pilot use, whereas from M36 we will continuously receive feedback from actual users via an issue tracking and prioritization tool and will modify/ optimize the tool, a final version of which will be available by the end of the project. Through the citizens engagement tool, citizens will be able to a) get convenient access to easy-to-understand information on episodes of extreme heat and/or air pollution; b) get automated alerts, triggered when a parameter exceeds limit values, for the specific user profile; c) receive customized information on everyday activities such as traveling, commuting and sports activities, based on their location. d) report their perception on extreme heat / air quality on specific locations. Regarding the security of the platform, we apply security best practices, ensuring that users’ personal information are not accessible by third parties.Outcome of T6.7

First version of citizens engagement tool

User survey and testing of first version of tool and first round of interaction with users. The first version of the tool will be offered to EFA, Quercus and the general public for pilot use. Through the citizens engagement tool, citizens will be able to a) get convenient access to easy-to-understand information on episodes of extreme heat and/or air pollution; b) get automated alerts, triggered when a parameter exceeds limit values, for the specific user profile; c) receive customized information on everyday activities such as traveling, commuting and sports activities, based on their location. d) report their perception on extreme heat / air quality on specific locations. Outcome of T6.7

Data management plan

Updates for the data management plan are foreseen with every periodic report and project review Part of T12
